Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal requests funds to support travel and associated costs for CANS 2010, an annual symposium that historically has alternated each year between a location in the U.S. and China. The symposium is expected to draw 60-70 people. On the U.S. side, this proposal supports travel costs for up to 11 participants, and costs associated with running the event such as meeting space rental and a/v equipment. 5 graduate students or young investigators will be supported in their participation as well. Letters of support from the Chinese Acadamy of Sciences (CAS) and CERNET, the two primary advanced networking funding and operational organizations (SAC through their CNIC division) in China, appear in the proposal and are described as long standing partners in CANS. The symposium is intended to enable the exchange of ideas (the proposal's intellectual merit) that, the proposal claims, would not otherwise happen between leaders and network researchers in the U.S. and China. Broader impact is referenced as the ongoing interactions and collaborations resulting from this and previous such events. The event is scheduled for September 19-21.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2010 Chinese American Network Symposium (CANS) was held from September 19-21, 2010 in Washington, D.C. The meeting was coordinated jointly by Internet2 and Georgetown University, which served as the local host, and co-sponsored by the Chinese Association for Science and Technology (CAST-USA), the Chinese Education and Research Network (CERNET), and the Chinese Science and Technology Network (CSTNET) of the Chinese Academy of Sciences.  CANS 2010 brought together U.S. and Chinese academic domain researchers and scientists, network researchers and network leaders involved in the design and use of high-performance research networks and applications.  Through this meeting, participants were able to promote understanding between the U.S. and China research networking communities, share information about their work, establish relationships, explore new collaborations, and report on progress from previously established partnerships. Sessions focused on the network research area and its role in the future development of cyberinfrastructure to support eScience, interoperability between the research infrastructures established in each country, and international science and research collaborations across a broad range of disciplines between the U.S. and China. 

 

The intellectual merit of CANS2010 was based on the international exchange of ideas this meeting fostered, which would otherwise not have occurred between Chinese and U.S. researchers. Findings include: recognition of the ongoing challenge of stable end-to-end network performance from the end-user/researcher to either another end-user or remote computational or data resources (particularly in a global context); the necessity of data exchange in support of collaborative research; and issues related to the often tight coupling between advanced networking, applications, and information technology.  Discussion at the workshop included improvement of connectivity quality and performance between US and Chinese campuses and research institutes, rather than only across backbone networks, and the role of monitoring tools that would permit the sharing of network performance data while maintaining the security of sensitive data. All of this occurred within the larger context of shared international goals among the U.S. participants, including: supporting the increasing number of U.S. universities deploying campuses and global programs in China; the need to support distributed educational capabilities on an international scale; timely deployment and joint development of applications to support IPv6 in China and the U.S.; and transformative applications that leverage high-performance global networks.
